Hi Ken,

If it's not to much trouble I'd like to ask you a few basic 
questions about specific implementation details in NEAT. Just to 
explain where I'm coming from. I sat down last night with the 
intention of porting one of the available NEAT projects (yours, 
JNEAT, etc) to C#. However, for now I have decided to attempt my own 
implementation rather than a direct port, for my own education as 
much as anything. I also have a quantity of existing code that can 
be restructured to implement NEAT so hopefully it shouldn't actually 
require much effort.

Anyway, I was looking through your code and couldn't quite determine 
how you treat node genes and specifically input node genes during 
evolution.

Some questions then:

1) I see from your recent email that you (optionally) allow input 
nodes to be removed. Do you also allow input nodes to be added?

2) Can I assume that you do not allow connections back *to* input 
nodes? and that therefore the connections you generate during 
evolution ignore input nodes as possible targets?

3) How do you 'inject' input signals into a network? Do you simply 
obtain a list of all the input nodes (in the order they exist within 
the genome) and directly set their output value? 

4) Not really a question, just an observation. In your original NEAT 
paper you do not mention whether both node and connection genes 
feature in the compatibilty function. A brief look at your code 
seems to indicate that only connection genes are considered. I guess 
this makes sense so long as mutation never changes a connection's 
end points - the connections therefore describe the network, the 
node genes are just placeholders. In fact I see you combined the 
function of node gene and working neuron, thus increasing 
efficiency - as there is no need to rebuild nn's at each evaluation.


Any assistance gratefully received!


In case others are interested I have been working with C# for my day 
job for about 9 months. I have a tendency to avoid MS products but I 
have to say I have been pleasantly surprised with the whole C#/.Net 
model. It is very much like java (and syntactically like C++) but is 
incredibly easy to code, MS have really put some though into the 
language identifying and addressing problems with Java/C++. 

Speed wise some rough tests showed that compiled C# runs at about 
80% the speed of optimised C++. I would imagine this is on a par 
with a modern Java VM. When I originally started tinkering with 
EANN's I developed with KDevelop (C++ IDE) on Linux, however I found 
I spent 90% of my time addressing issues with the IDE, the various 
C++ libraries (including a bug in the STL!), memory leaks and silly 
hidden bugs that seem inherent to large C++ projects. My experience 
with C# thus far has been a breath of fresh air in comparison, many 
of the sources of silly bugs are immediately highlighted (if you can 
afford Visual Studio that is!) and the .Net framework has proved 
very robust.

In terms of a platform for experimentation I think it is ideal. I 
should also point out that the SDK(including a C# compiler) and the 
framework itself are freely available and that there is an open 
source IDE (SharpDevelop) if you don't wan't to pay for Microsoft's 
IDE. It's certainly worth a look anyhow if you haven't already.

Cheers,

Colin.
